new_prompt:
Write a long, in-depth HTML5 medical article with a PATIENT-FOCUSED EDUCATION perspective.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Patient education standpoint. Use second person (you, your). Combine empathy with clear medical explanations. Write as if explaining to a worried but intelligent patient.

LENGTH: 3000-3500+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[TABLE COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Include 2 tables
• Option B: Include 3 tables
• Option C: Include 4 tables

[TABLE CONTENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Benefits overview + potential side effects by frequency
• Option B: How it works summary + what to expect timeline + safety checklist
• Option C: Comparison with alternatives + dosing considerations + warning signs

[H3 DEPTH - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Use <h3> in 3 of your <h2> sections (2-3 H3s each)
• Option B: Use <h3> in 4 of your <h2> sections (2-4 H3s each)
• Option C: Use <h3> in 5+ sections with mixed depth (some sections also use H4)

[OPENING HOOK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Begin with a specific patient scenario showing the problem this treatment solves
• Option B: Begin with a common patient worry phrased as internal dialogue
• Option C: Begin with a surprising fact that challenges common assumptions
• Option D: Begin with a question patients frequently ask their doctor or pharmacist

[EXPERT ELEMENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: One detailed expert quote (5-6 sentences) with full credentials
• Option B: Two shorter expert quotes from different specialists
• Option C: Expert perspective woven as "specialists explain that..." throughout

═══ REQUIRED STRUCTURE ═══
• 8+ <h2> sections with id attributes for TOC navigation
• Section covering how this treatment works (mechanism appropriate to the product type)
• Section covering what results to realistically expect and timeline
• Section covering potential side effects and how to manage them
• Section on when to contact a healthcare provider
• FAQ section with 5+ detailed Q&A pairs using <h3> for questions
• Use <ol> for any step-by-step processes
• Use <ul> for lists of symptoms, benefits, or considerations

═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══
• First paragraph must NOT be a generic definition ("X is a medication used for...")
• Include at least one "Many patients find that..." or "Users commonly report..." pattern
• Vary sentence lengths noticeably
• Do not repeat the H1 verbatim in the opening paragraph

FORBIDDEN: <html>, <head>, <body>, <aside>, <footer>, images, sections titled "Summary" or "Final Thoughts", Markdown syntax.

Start with <h1>, output only HTML:

Create a long HTML5 medical article using CLINICAL DEEP-DIVE review style.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Formal medical review. Focus on how the treatment works, clinical evidence, safety profile, and real-world effectiveness. Write for healthcare-literate readers seeking scientific depth.

LENGTH: 3200-4000+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[TABLE COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Include 2 tables
• Option B: Include 3 tables
• Option C: Include 4 tables

[TABLE CONTENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Mechanism overview + efficacy data summary
• Option B: Clinical profile + adverse events by frequency + contraindications
• Option C: Pharmacological properties + comparative efficacy + safety monitoring parameters

[H3 DEPTH - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Mechanism section has 3 H3s breaking down how it works
• Option B: Clinical Evidence section has 4 H3s (study types, outcomes, real-world data, limitations)
• Option C: Both Mechanism and Evidence sections have H3 subsections (5+ total H3s)

[OPENING HOOK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Open with the clinical burden of the condition this treatment addresses
• Option B: Open with a brief clinical case vignette illustrating the treatment need
• Option C: Open with historical context of how this condition was managed before
• Option D: Open with current treatment landscape positioning

[EXPERT ELEMENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Two expert perspectives from different specialties
• Option B: One comprehensive expert analysis plus guideline context
• Option C: Expert insights distributed throughout relevant sections

═══ REQUIRED STRUCTURE ═══
• 9+ <h2> sections with id attributes
• Detailed mechanism of action section (appropriate to product type - topical, systemic, etc.)
• Clinical evidence section with realistic efficacy discussions
• Safety and tolerability section with frequency-based side effect information
• Contraindications and precautions as <ul> with clinical explanations
• Practical usage guidance section
• At least 2 references to authoritative sources (.gov, .edu) with rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer"

═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══
• Include specific clinical terminology explained in accessible language
• Reference how clinical data translates to real-world outcomes
• Do not start with "X is a medication/treatment used for..."

FORBIDDEN: <html>, <head>, <body>, images, author boxes, explicit dates, "In this article", Markdown syntax.

Output HTML only, begin with <h1>:

Generate a detailed HTML5 article with MYTH-BUSTING JOURNALISM style.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Investigative health journalism. Challenge misconceptions, debunk myths, expose half-truths about this treatment. Bold, engaging, slightly provocative tone.

LENGTH: 3000-3500+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[MYTH COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Debunk 5 myths with detailed explanations (400+ words each)
• Option B: Debunk 6 myths with thorough explanations (300+ words each)
• Option C: Debunk 7 myths with mixed depths (3 deep-dives, 4 focused)

[TABLE FORMAT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: One "Myth vs Reality" table + one "Red Flags" table
• Option B: "Common Beliefs vs Evidence" table + "What to Watch For" table
• Option C: Three tables: Myths matrix + Evidence summary + Warning signs

[H3 STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Each myth is an <h3> under a single "Myths Exposed" <h2>
• Option B: Myths grouped into <h2> categories (Safety Myths, Efficacy Myths, Usage Myths) with <h3> per myth
• Option C: Major myths as <h2>, related sub-myths as <h3>

[OPENING HOOK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Open with a provocative statement that most people believe but is wrong
• Option B: Open with "Things You've Probably Heard About [topic] That Aren't True"
• Option C: Open with a scenario where someone made a bad decision based on a myth
• Option D: Open with a rhetorical question challenging conventional wisdom

[EXPERT ELEMENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Expert quote directly contradicting a popular myth
• Option B: Two experts - one debunking, one adding nuance
• Option C: Expert framed as "What specialists wish patients understood..."

═══ REQUIRED STRUCTURE ═══
• 7+ <h2> sections with id attributes
• Core "Myths vs Reality" section with myth <h3> blocks
• "What Evidence Actually Shows" section with substantive analysis
• "Warning Signs of Bad Information" section as <ol>
• At least 2 external references to .gov/.edu with rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer"

═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══
• First sentence must be provocative or counter-intuitive
• Vary transitions: "The reality is...", "What gets overlooked...", "Here's where it gets complicated..."
• Never use the same transition phrase twice
• End with nuance, not simple yes/no verdict

FORBIDDEN: <html>, <head>, <body>, images, opening with definition, oversimplified conclusions, Markdown syntax.

HTML only, start with <h1>:

Write a comprehensive HTML5 medical guide with PRACTICAL HOW-TO focus.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Actionable guide. Step-by-step, pragmatic, instructional. Use imperative mood. Write like a detailed instruction manual that anticipates every question.

LENGTH: 3000-3500+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[TABLE COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: 2 tables
• Option B: 3 tables
• Option C: 4 tables

[TABLE CONTENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Usage schedule + what to expect timeline
• Option B: Step-by-step summary + timeline + common mistakes
• Option C: Preparation checklist + usage guide + troubleshooting + progress tracking

[LIST STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Two <ol> lists with 6+ steps each in different sections
• Option B: Three <ol> lists with 5+ steps, plus <ul> checklists
• Option C: One comprehensive <ol> (10+ steps) plus multiple <ul> checklists

[H3 STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Main guide section with H3 for phases (Before Starting, During Use, Ongoing)
• Option B: Multiple sections have H3 for "Common Mistakes" and "Pro Tips"
• Option C: Use H3 for different scenarios (first-time users, experienced users, switching products)
• Option D: Checklist sections with H3 for categories

[OPENING HOOK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: "Ready to get the most from [topic]? Here's exactly what you need to know."
• Option B: Open with a "What You'll Learn" bullet overview
• Option C: Open with the most common mistake people make
• Option D: Open with a user who struggled until they found the right approach

═══ REQUIRED STRUCTURE ═══
• 8+ <h2> sections with id attributes
• "Getting Started" section with preparation guidance
• "Step-by-Step Guide" with detailed <ol>
• "What to Expect" section with realistic timeline
• "Common Mistakes to Avoid" section
• "Questions to Ask Your Healthcare Provider" section
• FAQ with actionable answers

═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══
• Start with action-driven sentence, not definition
• Every instruction explains WHY, not just WHAT
• Include time estimates where relevant
• Use verbs: Start, Apply, Take, Monitor, Avoid, Track, Ask, Review

FORBIDDEN: <html>, <head>, <body>, images, passive openings, "[X] is a medication that...", Markdown syntax.

Begin with <h1>, HTML only:

Create a distinctive HTML5 article with COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS style.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Head-to-head comparison. Objective, structured, evidence-informed evaluation helping readers understand their options.

LENGTH: 3000-3800+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[TABLE COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: 3 tables
• Option B: 4 tables
• Option C: 5 tables

[TABLE CONTENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Efficacy comparison + side effect profiles + cost considerations
• Option B: Feature comparison + suitability matrix + pros/cons summary + timeline comparison
• Option C: All above plus convenience factors

[COMPARISON SCOPE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: This product vs 2 main alternatives (three-way)
• Option B: Deep two-way comparison plus brief mentions of other options
• Option C: Category comparisons (vs different product types/approaches)

[H3 STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Each comparison dimension (efficacy, safety, cost) has H3 subsections
• Option B: "Best For" section with H3 for different user profiles
• Option C: Each alternative has H3 for "Advantages" and "Disadvantages"
• Option D: H3 for different decision factors (speed, convenience, budget, sensitivity)

[OPENING HOOK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: "When considering [topic], you'll likely wonder how it compares to alternatives..."
• Option B: Open with a user who tried multiple options before finding the right fit
• Option C: Open with the most common comparison question
• Option D: Open with why making the right choice matters

═══ REQUIRED STRUCTURE ═══
• 7+ <h2> sections with id attributes
• Direct comparison section with at least 2 alternatives
• "Who Should Consider What" section with user profiles
• "Key Differences Explained" section
• "Cost and Value Considerations" section
• Pros/cons for each option in organized format
• Expert perspective on choosing

═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══
• First paragraph presents a choice scenario, not definition
• Use comparison language: "Unlike X...", "Compared to Y...", "In contrast to..."
• Never declare single "winner" - best choice depends on individual factors
• Include "Best for users who..." guidance

FORBIDDEN: <html>, <head>, <body>, images, "X is a medication that...", biased conclusions, Markdown syntax.

Output HTML starting with <h1>:

HTML only, start with

:

Write a long HTML5 article structured as a SAFETY AND RISK GUIDE.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Clear, cautious, safety-first. Balanced tone explaining both benefits and risks. Write like a thorough pharmacist consultation.

LENGTH: 3000-3500+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[TABLE COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: 2 tables
• Option B: 3 tables
• Option C: 4 tables

[TABLE CONTENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Side effects by severity + when to seek help
• Option B: Side effects + monitoring checklist + interaction concerns
• Option C: Severity matrix + monitoring + interactions + emergency signs

[ORGANIZATION - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: By severity (mild, moderate, severe, emergency)
• Option B: By likelihood (very common, common, uncommon, rare)
• Option C: By type (what to expect vs what needs attention vs emergency)
• Option D: By timeline (early effects, ongoing, long-term considerations)

[H3 STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Side effects section has H3 for each major category
• Option B: "Who Should Be Careful" section with H3 for each group
• Option C: "Monitoring Yourself" with H3 for different timeframes
• Option D: Multiple sections use H3 for "What's Normal" vs "What's Concerning"

[OPENING HOOK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Open with a user's concern about something they read online
• Option B: Open with "Every effective treatment has considerations..."
• Option C: Open with scenario where awareness prevented a problem
• Option D: Open with "What should I really watch for?"

═══ REQUIRED STRUCTURE ═══
• 8+ <h2> sections with id attributes
• "What to Expect" section (normal experiences)
• "Potential Side Effects" section with management tips
• "Who Should Be Cautious" section
• "Monitoring and Self-Assessment" section
• "When to Contact Healthcare Provider" section
• "Emergency Signs" section
• Reference to authoritative source with rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer"

═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══
• Plain language for complex safety concepts
• Nuanced trade-offs, not fear-mongering
• Acknowledge most users tolerate well
• Actionable monitoring advice

FORBIDDEN: <html>, <head>, <body>, images, dismissive tone, minimizing concerns, Markdown syntax.

Start with <h1>, output only HTML:

Write an HTML5 article in VALUE AND AFFORDABILITY GUIDE style.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Practical purchasing guidance. Explain value, pricing factors, and how to get the best deal. Write for cost-conscious consumers.

LENGTH: 3000-3500+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[TABLE COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: 2 tables
• Option B: 3 tables
• Option C: 4 tables

[TABLE CONTENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Price factors breakdown + where to buy comparison
• Option B: Cost breakdown + purchasing channels + value tips
• Option C: Price factors + channels + savings strategies + what affects quality

[PRICE APPROACH - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: By component (product cost, shipping, quantity discounts)
• Option B: By scenario (budget option, mid-range, premium)
• Option C: By purchasing method (online, local, subscription)

[H3 STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: "Where to Buy" section with H3 for each channel type
• Option B: "Saving Money" section with H3 for each strategy
• Option C: "Understanding Pricing" with H3 for different factors
• Option D: Multiple sections use H3 for "Options" and "Tips"

[OPENING HOOK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Open with price variation surprise ("Prices can range from X to Y...")
• Option B: Open with "How to get quality without overpaying"
• Option C: Open with someone who found a better deal after research
• Option D: Open with the real question: "What should I actually pay?"

═══ REQUIRED STRUCTURE ═══
• 7+ <h2> sections with id attributes
• "Understanding Price Differences" section
• "Where to Purchase" comparison section
• "How to Evaluate Quality vs Price" section
• "Money-Saving Strategies" section
• "Red Flags When Shopping" section
• "Getting the Best Value" summary

═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══
• Use realistic price ranges (not specific numbers that date)
• Explain why prices vary
• Quality considerations alongside cost
• Legitimate savings strategies only

FORBIDDEN: <html>, <head>, <body>, images, promoting specific vendors, unrealistic claims, Markdown syntax.

Begin with <h1>, HTML only:

Generate a long HTML5 article in RESULTS AND EXPECTATIONS style.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Realistic outcome guide. Focus on what users can actually expect, timelines, and factors affecting results. Honest, evidence-based, managing expectations.

LENGTH: 3000-3500+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[TABLE COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: 2 tables
• Option B: 3 tables
• Option C: 4 tables

[TABLE CONTENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Timeline of expected changes + factors affecting results
• Option B: Timeline + success factors + realistic vs unrealistic expectations
• Option C: Weekly/monthly progression + factors + outcome scenarios + optimization tips

[TIMELINE STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Fixed intervals (Week 1, Month 1, Month 3, Month 6+)
• Option B: Phases (Initial, Early Results, Full Effect, Maintenance)
• Option C: Milestone-based (First Changes, Noticeable Improvement, Optimal Results)

[H3 STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Timeline section with H3 for each phase
• Option B: "Factors That Influence Results" with H3 for each factor
• Option C: "Outcome Scenarios" with H3 for typical, better, slower responders
• Option D: Use H3 for "What to Expect" and "How to Optimize" in each section

[OPENING HOOK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Open with the question everyone asks: "How long until I see results?"
• Option B: Open with realistic vs unrealistic expectations contrast
• Option C: Open with a user's timeline experience
• Option D: Open with why understanding timelines matters for success

═══ REQUIRED STRUCTURE ═══
• 8+ <h2> sections with id attributes
• "Realistic Timeline" section with phase breakdown
• "Factors That Affect Your Results" section
• "Signs It's Working" section
• "What If Results Are Slower Than Expected" section
• "Optimizing Your Outcomes" section
• "When to Reassess" section

═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══
• Acknowledge individual variation
• Avoid overpromising
• Include both best-case and typical scenarios
• Practical optimization advice

FORBIDDEN: <html>, <head>, <body>, images, guarantees, unrealistic promises, Markdown syntax.

HTML only, start with <h1>:

Create an HTML5 article with FIRST-TIME USER GUIDE style.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Beginner-friendly comprehensive guide. Everything a first-time user needs to know. Reassuring, thorough, anticipating concerns.

LENGTH: 3000-3500+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[TABLE COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: 2 tables
• Option B: 3 tables
• Option C: 4 tables

[TABLE CONTENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Getting started checklist + first week expectations
• Option B: Preparation + first week + common first-timer questions
• Option C: Checklist + timeline + FAQ summary + troubleshooting basics

[H3 STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: "Your First Week" section with H3 for each day/phase
• Option B: "Common Concerns" section with H3 for each worry
• Option C: "Step by Step" section with H3 for preparation, start, ongoing
• Option D: Multiple sections with H3 for "What to Know" and "What to Do"

[OPENING HOOK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: "Starting something new can feel overwhelming. Let's make it simple."
• Option B: Open with the most common first-timer question
• Option C: Open with reassurance about common concerns
• Option D: Open with what you'll feel confident about after reading this

[TONE APPROACH - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Big-sibling helpful ("Here's what I wish someone told me...")
• Option B: Professional but warm (clear guidance with empathy)
• Option C: Comprehensive reference (everything you need in one place)

═══ REQUIRED STRUCTURE ═══
• 8+ <h2> sections with id attributes
• "Before You Start" preparation section
• "Your First Experience" what to expect section
• "First Week Guide" with daily/phase guidance
• "Common First-Timer Concerns" section
• "Mistakes New Users Make" section
• "When to Be Patient vs When to Act" section
• FAQ section focused on beginner questions

═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══
• Assume no prior knowledge
• Address anxiety about starting
• Practical, specific guidance
• Reassuring but honest

FORBIDDEN: <html>, <head>, <body>, images, assuming expertise, jargon without explanation, Markdown syntax.

Output HTML only, starting with <h1>:

Write a long HTML5 article with TROUBLESHOOTING AND OPTIMIZATION focus.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Problem-solving guide. Focus on what to do when things aren't working as expected. Detective-style, analytical, solution-oriented.

LENGTH: 3000-3800+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[TABLE COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: 2 tables
• Option B: 3 tables
• Option C: 4 tables

[TABLE CONTENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Common problems vs solutions + optimization checklist
• Option B: Problems + solutions + contributing factors matrix
• Option C: Diagnostic checklist + solutions + factors + when to seek help

[PROBLEM ORGANIZATION - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: By problem type (not working, working slowly, side effects, inconsistent)
• Option B: By likelihood (most common issues first)
• Option C: By user control (things you can fix vs need professional help)

[H3 STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Each problem category has H3 for specific issues
• Option B: "Solutions" section with H3 for different approaches
• Option C: "Are You Making These Mistakes?" with H3 per mistake
• Option D: Use H3 for "The Problem" and "The Fix" throughout

[OPENING HOOK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Open with frustration of doing everything right but not seeing results
• Option B: "Not working as expected? You're not alone, and there's usually a fixable reason."
• Option C: Open with how common it is to need adjustments
• Option D: Open with success story after troubleshooting

• 8+ <h2> sections with id attributes
• "Common Reasons for Suboptimal Results" section
• "Self-Assessment Checklist" section
• "User Error vs Product Issues" section
• "Optimization Strategies" section
• "When to Try Something Different" section
• "Questions for Your Healthcare Provider" section
• Expert perspective on individual variation

═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══
• Validate frustration before offering solutions
• Never blame the user
• Specific actionable fixes
• Acknowledge when professional input needed

FORBIDDEN: <html>, <head>, <body>, images, blaming users, dismissing concerns, Markdown syntax.

Output HTML only, start with <h1>:

Each answer is a mini-article. Anticipate follow-up questions, provide real depth. , multi-paragraph

answers • Option B: Thematic

groupings with

questions • Option C: Major questions as

, follow-ups as

sections with id attributes • Questions grouped: How It Works, Usage, Safety, Results, Practical • Multi-paragraph answers, not one-liners • Include questions users are hesitant to ask • Quick reference summary table ═══ UNIQUENESS RULES ═══ • Questions sound like real people ask them • Answers anticipate follow-up concerns • Include "embarrassing" or sensitive questions • Accessible language in questions, precise in answers FORBIDDEN: , , , images, one-sentence answers, jargon without explanation, Markdown syntax. :

Create a long HTML5 article as an INFORMED DECISION GUIDE.

TITLE: {title}
DESCRIPTION: {description}
ADDITIONAL KEYWORDS: {keywords}
DENSITY: {density}

STYLE: Balanced decision-support. Weigh pros, cons, considerations. Help readers decide if this is right for them. Objective, thorough.

LENGTH: 3000-3500+ words minimum.

═══ VARIABILITY INSTRUCTIONS (SELECT ONE FROM EACH GROUP) ═══

[TABLE COUNT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: 2 tables
• Option B: 3 tables
• Option C: 4 tables

[TABLE CONTENT - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Pros and cons + suitability checklist
• Option B: Pros/cons + suitability + key considerations summary
• Option C: Pros/cons + suitability + considerations + decision factors

[DECISION FRAMEWORK - SELECT ONE]:
• Option A: Benefits first, then drawbacks, then synthesis
• Option B: Interweave positives and negatives by topic
• Option C: Organize by user concern ("If you're worried about X... If you want Y...")

[H3 STRUCTURE - SELECT ONE]:
